wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the overall credit-card-tracker application. Explain its purpose as a financial tracking tool for credit card spending, installments, and BNPL purchases. Describe the architecture as a full-stack Next.js application using App Router, Supabase for backend services, and a component-based UI with daisyUI and Tailwind CSS. Document the implementation details including password-based authentication, data modeling for financial entities, and automatic transaction generation. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Provide practical examples demonstrating common user workflows such as adding purchases and tracking payments. Use terminology consistent with the codebase like 'installments', 'transactions', and 'credit cards'. Include diagrams illustrating the high-level system architecture and data flow between components.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Endpoints
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the /api/site-auth endpoint in the credit-card-tracker application. Document that it accepts POST requests with a JSON body containing a 'password' field. On success (HTTP 200), it returns a JSON response with { message: 'Authentication successful' } and sets a secure, httpOnly cookie named 'site_access_token' with a 7-day expiration. On failure, it returns appropriate error codes: 400 for missing password, 401 for invalid password, and 500 for server misconfiguration. Include details about cookie security settings (secure in production, sameSite=lax) and the role of this endpoint in the overall authentication flow. Provide example request/response pairs and explain how clients should handle authentication state.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Hierarchy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the frontend component hierarchy of the credit-card-tracker application. Describe the root layout structure using AppSidebar for desktop navigation and BottomNavigation for mobile, with responsive display controlled via Tailwind CSS classes. Document the component organization by feature domains (credit-cards, persons, purchases, transactions) and shared base components (Button, Input, Card, etc.). Explain the composition pattern where feature pages utilize specialized forms (CreditCardForm, PersonForm, PurchaseForm) and data display components (DataTable, TransactionFilters). Include system context diagrams showing parent-child relationships between layout, pages, and components. Address cross-cutting concerns like responsive design breakpoints, accessibility attributes, and consistent styling through the design system in src/styles/design-system. Provide guidelines for creating new feature components and integrating them into the existing hierarchy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AuthService class in the credit-card-tracker application. Explain its purpose in handling user authentication via password submission to the /api/site-auth endpoint. Document the static methods: authenticate (which performs a fetch request and sets localStorage upon success), isAuthenticated (which checks localStorage state), and logout (which clears authentication state). Include code examples showing how the service is used in the enter-password page and protected by middleware. Explain the client-side nature of this service using 'use client', and describe integration with the API route and middleware for route protection. Address common issues such as failed authentication responses, CORS considerations, and localStorage persistence across sessions. Provide guidance on extending the service for token-based authentication or biometric login in the future.

wiki_catalogs.name: Navigation Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the navigation components in the credit-card-tracker application. Explain the dual navigation system: AppSidebar for desktop layouts using responsive design with Tailwind CSS, and BottomNavigation/NavigationBar for mobile and tablet views. Document how NAV_LINKS from constants are mapped to dynamic icons using getNavigationIcon from icons.ts. Describe the composition of NavigationBar as a horizontal menu with NavLink wrappers around route paths. Include usage examples showing how to add new navigation items while maintaining accessibility and responsive behavior. Address integration with Next.js App Router, active link styling, and data-component attributes for testing. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like incorrect icon rendering or broken routes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Form Controls
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for form control components used across the credit-card-tracker application. Explain the implementation of Input with label, error, and help text integration using daisyUI's form-control classes. Document Select component's variant and size options with proper option formatting. Describe Textarea's extensibility and accessibility features. Detail Checkbox's boolean state handling and DateInput's date formatting behavior. Analyze FormSelect as a higher-level abstraction wrapping shadcn/ui's Select with form-friendly event handling. Provide examples of form composition using these controls with Zod validation through useZodForm hook. Include guidance on error state management, required field handling, and responsive form layouts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Credit Card Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CreditCardForm component used in the credit card management feature. Explain its implementation using Zod validation schema through the useZodForm hook, integration with the creditCardService for CRUD operations, and handling of supplementary card relationships. Document form fields including card name, issuer, cardholder name, and last four digits, along with UI behavior such as real-time validation and error messaging. Include examples of how this component is used within the /credit-cards page and composed with base components like Input and Button. Address state management, error handling during submission, and accessibility considerations. Provide guidance on extending the form for new card attributes or validation rules.

wiki_catalogs.name: Purchase Form
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the PurchaseForm component, which handles complex purchase data entry including credit card selection, person assignment, purchase date, description, total amount, number of installments, and BNPL (Buy Now, Pay Later) status. Explain how the form integrates with Zod for schema validation through the useZodForm hook to ensure data integrity before submission. Document the interaction with purchaseService to create or update purchases and trigger automatic transaction generation for installments. Include examples of how PurchaseForm is used within a Modal for inline editing on the purchases page. Address form state management, error handling, responsive layout using Tailwind CSS, and accessibility considerations such as proper labeling and keyboard navigation. Provide code snippets demonstrating validation rules, dynamic field behavior (e.g., installment count affecting transaction scheduling), and integration with Supabase via service layer.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of the credit-card-tracker application. Explain the role of Next.js 15 with App Router as the foundation, React 19 for component architecture, and TypeScript for type safety. Detail the use of Supabase for database and authentication services, Tailwind CSS with daisyUI for styling, and Zod for schema validation. Document configuration options in next.config.ts, tsconfig.json, and postcss.config.mjs. Include practical examples showing how these technologies integrate, such as using Supabase client in services and Tailwind classes in components. Explain the benefits of this stack for building a secure financial tracking application. Address common setup issues and their solutions, such as environment variable configuration and dependency version compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the authentication flow in the credit-card-tracker application. Explain the sequence: user enters password on /enter-password page → client-side AuthService makes POST request to /api/site-auth → server validates password against SITE_PASSWORD environment variable → on success, sets httpOnly cookie → middleware checks for valid cookie on subsequent requests and redirects to /enter-password if missing. Document the role of PUBLIC_PATHS in bypassing authentication, the 7-day cookie expiration, and client-side localStorage synchronization for UI state. Include error handling for invalid passwords and server errors. Explain security considerations like cookie security (httpOnly, secure in production) and protection of the SITE_PASSWORD environment variable.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the state management system in the credit-card-tracker application. Thoroughly explain the implementation of custom React hooks useZodForm and usePurchaseDetails, including their interfaces, domain models, and usage patterns. For useZodForm, document how it integrates Zod schema validation with form state, handles different input types (text, number, checkbox), and provides error management. For usePurchaseDetails, explain how it manages asynchronous data loading for purchase details and related transactions, handles loading states and errors, and provides transaction status update functionality. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase demonstrating hook usage in PurchaseForm and PurchaseDetailsCard. Address common issues like stale closures, dependency array configuration, and error handling. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers regarding performance optimization and best practices for custom hook design.

wiki_catalogs.name: Credit Card Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CreditCardService class that manages CRUD operations for credit cards in the Supabase database. Thoroughly explain each method: loadCards (with relationship expansion for principal cards), createCard, updateCard, and deleteCard. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how the service interacts with the Supabase client using select, insert, update, and delete operations. Document the transformation logic that adds the 'expand' property for UI consumption. Explain the relationship between supplementary and principal cards in the data model. Address error handling patterns, promise-based returns, and integration with the CreditCardForm component. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like foreign key constraints, invalid card data, and synchronization delays. Include performance considerations such as data fetching optimization and caching strategies for frequently accessed card lists.

wiki_catalogs.name: Base UI Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the base UI components library used throughout the credit-card-tracker application. Detail each primitive component's props, styling via Tailwind CSS, and accessibility features. Explain how base components like Input, Select, and Button are extended into higher-level abstractions like FormSelect and Modal. Document the integration with shadcn/ui components (table, select) and their customization through the design system in src/styles/design-system. Include practical examples demonstrating form composition with Label, Input, and Error states. Address responsive behaviors, loading states with LoadingSpinner, and keyboard navigation support. Provide guidelines for consistent usage and extension while maintaining design system integrity.

wiki_catalogs.name: Interactive Elements
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for interactive UI components that enable user actions and feedback. Detail Button's extensive customization options including color, variant, size, and modifier props with daisyUI integration. Explain the as prop for rendering buttons as anchor or input elements with appropriate accessibility attributes. Document Modal's controlled open/close behavior, backdrop dismissal, and responsive sizing via maxWidth prop. Describe LoadingSpinner's usage within buttons and standalone loading states. Provide examples of combining Button with Modal for confirmation dialogs, and Button with LoadingSpinner for async operation feedback. Address accessibility concerns like focus management, keyboard navigation, and ARIA attributes across these components.

wiki_catalogs.name: Person Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the PersonForm component used in the person management feature. Explain its implementation using Zod validation via useZodForm hook, integration with personService for data persistence, and handling of person creation and editing workflows. Document form structure, input validation rules, and submission handling including loading states and error feedback. Describe how this component is integrated into the /persons page and composed with base UI components like Input and Button. Address accessibility features, responsive design considerations, and error boundary handling. Provide best practices for reusing this component pattern when adding new entity forms to the application.

wiki_catalogs.name: Purchase Details Card
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the PurchaseDetailsCard component, which displays comprehensive information about a selected purchase in a structured layout. Explain how it renders key fields such as purchase description, date, total amount, associated credit card (including issuer, last four digits, and supplementary status), person responsible, number of installments, and BNPL status. Document the use of expand objects from Supabase to access related data (credit_card and person) and handle potential null values gracefully. Describe the formatting of currency using CURRENCY_DECIMAL_PLACES constant and date formatting via formatDate utility. Highlight the responsive grid layout that adapts from single column on mobile to two columns on desktop. Include examples of how this component is used within the purchases/[id]/page.tsx to show detailed purchase breakdowns. Address UI/UX considerations such as visual hierarchy, spacing, and readability, and explain integration patterns with parent components and data fetching strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Directory Structure Breakdown
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the project's directory structure. Explain the purpose of each top-level directory: src/app for Next.js App Router pages and API routes, src/components for reusable UI components organized by feature domain, src/lib for business logic and services, and src/styles/design-system for design system configuration. Document the organization patterns within each directory, such as feature-based grouping in components and service pattern implementation in lib. Include practical examples from the actual codebase showing how files are organized, such as credit card components in src/components/credit-cards and services in src/lib/services. Address common navigation issues and best practices for maintaining this structure as the application grows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Service Layer Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the service layer in the credit-card-tracker application. Describe the service pattern implementation where each service class (PersonService, CreditCardService, etc.) encapsulates data access logic and interacts with the Supabase client. Document the separation between client-side services (using 'use client') and server-side data operations. Explain how services handle CRUD operations, error logging, and promise-based returns. Detail the dependency on the centralized supabase client instance and type definitions from supabase.ts. Provide examples from the codebase showing service usage patterns and explain how new services should be structured to maintain consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Routing Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the routing structure of the credit-card-tracker application using Next.js App Router. Describe the file-based routing system with nested directories for features like purchases/[id] and transactions/person/[id]. Explain the role of layout.tsx in providing a consistent shell across routes and handling responsive navigation with AppSidebar and BottomNavigation. Document the authentication middleware that protects routes by redirecting unauthenticated users to /enter-password. Detail the route handlers for key pages including home (/), credit-cards, persons, purchases, and transactions. Include diagrams illustrating the route hierarchy and navigation flow. Address dynamic routing parameters, route groups, and loading states. Provide guidelines for adding new routes while maintaining security and responsive design requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Person Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the PersonService class responsible for managing person records in the application. Explain implementation details of methods: loadPersons, addPerson, updatePerson, deletePerson, and loadPerson (by ID). Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how these methods use the Supabase client for data operations with proper error handling. Document the integration between the service and the PersonForm component in the persons page. Explain the data flow from form submission to database persistence and UI update. Address common issues such as duplicate person names, deletion constraints when persons are referenced by purchases, and loading states during asynchronous operations. Provide guidance on extending the service to support additional person attributes or search functionality. Include performance considerations for large datasets and potential pagination strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Feature-Specific Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the feature-specific components in the credit-card-tracker application. Explain how forms like CreditCardForm, PersonForm, and PurchaseForm encapsulate domain logic for their respective entities using Zod validation via useZodForm hook. Document the PurchaseDetailsCard for displaying installment breakdowns and TransactionFilters for filtering transaction lists by date and status. Describe the PasswordForm component's role in authentication flow with error handling. Include examples of component composition patterns, such as how PurchaseForm integrates with Modal for inline editing. Address state management strategies, error boundary handling, and integration with service layer APIs. Provide best practices for extending these components when adding new features.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Display Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document components responsible for structured data presentation in the application. Detail Card's composition pattern with Header and Body subcomponents, variant theming, and hover effects. Explain how Card integrates with the design system for consistent spacing and shadows. Describe Label's role in form contexts and accessibility. Analyze the shadcn/ui Table implementation for displaying transaction, purchase, and credit card data with sorting and pagination capabilities. Provide examples of Card usage with DataTable for feature pages like transactions and purchases. Include guidance on responsive data display, content hierarchy, and accessibility for screen readers when using these components.

wiki_catalogs.name: Purchase Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the purchase-related components including PurchaseForm, PurchaseDetailsCard, and PurchaseFilters. Explain how PurchaseForm handles complex purchase data entry with installment/BNPL options using Zod validation and integration with purchaseService. Document PurchaseDetailsCard's role in displaying installment breakdowns and payment schedules. Describe PurchaseFilters' functionality for filtering purchase lists by date range and status. Include examples of component composition such as PurchaseForm being used within Modal for inline editing, and how these components interact with usePurchaseDetails hook for dynamic data calculation. Address state management, form validation strategies, and responsive layout considerations across these components.

wiki_catalogs.name: Purchase Filters
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the PurchaseFilters component, which enables users to filter the list of purchases by person, credit card, payment status (paid/unpaid), and description search. Explain how the component accepts filter values and a callback function (onFilterChange) to propagate changes to the parent component. Document the implementation of Select components for person and card dropdowns, populated from props with mapped options showing relevant labels (e.g., card name and last four digits). Describe the text input for description filtering with real-time change handling and the paid status selector with 'All', 'Paid', and 'Unpaid' options. Include the functionality of the Clear Filters button that resets all filters to empty strings. Address the component's responsive flex layout and form control styling using daisyUI classes. Provide examples of how PurchaseFilters integrates with the purchases/page.tsx to control DataTable filtering and discuss performance considerations for re-renders when filter state changes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Frontend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the frontend architecture of the credit-card-tracker application. Describe the high-level design using Next.js App Router with server components for pages and client components for interactive elements. Document the component hierarchy with layout.tsx as the root layout, feature-specific pages, and reusable components. Explain the use of React hooks in src/lib/hooks for form management and purchase details. Include system context diagrams showing the relationship between layout, pages, and components. Address cross-cutting concerns like responsive design with AppSidebar and BottomNavigation, theming with Tailwind, and accessibility compliance. Provide guidelines for creating new components and integrating them into the existing architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Purchase Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the PurchaseService class that handles purchase and transaction data operations. Thoroughly explain the loadPurchaseDetails method that fetches a purchase with its related credit card and person data, along with all associated transactions. Detail the updateTransactionPaidStatus method that modifies transaction payment status in the database. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how purchase details are transformed to include expanded relationships for UI consumption. Explain the integration between this service and the purchase detail page, including data loading patterns and state management. Address common issues such as race conditions when updating transaction status, handling missing purchases, and error propagation to the UI. Provide guidance on extending the service to support purchase editing or bulk transaction updates. Include performance considerations for loading large transaction histories and potential data filtering optimizations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Display Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the data display components in the credit-card-tracker application. Focus on DataTable as a generic, reusable table component that accepts typed data and column definitions with customizable cells and headers. Explain its integration with shadcn/ui table primitives and responsive overflow handling. Document PurchaseDetailsCard's role in visualizing installment schedules and TransactionFilters for interactive filtering of transaction records. Include examples showing how these components consume data from services and render it efficiently using React best practices. Address performance considerations for large datasets, virtualization needs, and accessibility compliance for screen readers. Provide guidelines for creating new data display components following the same patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Transaction Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the TransactionFilters component used in transaction management. Explain its implementation for filtering transaction lists by date range and payment status, including UI controls and state management using client-side React state. Document integration with the dataService for fetching filtered transaction data and handling loading/error states. Describe the component's composition with base components like DateInput and Select, and its usage within the /transactions page. Address accessibility features, keyboard navigation support, and mobile responsiveness. Provide guidance on extending the filtering capabilities with additional criteria such as person or credit card filters.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the backend architecture of the credit-card-tracker application. Describe the high-level design with Supabase serving as the backend-as-a-service for database and authentication, Next.js API routes for custom endpoints, and middleware for request interception. Document the service pattern implementation in src/lib/services for data access abstraction. Explain the authentication flow from API endpoint to middleware protection. Include system context diagrams showing the interaction between API routes, services, Supabase client, and database. Address security considerations like cookie-based authentication and environment variable protection. Provide guidelines for creating new API endpoints and services while maintaining the existing architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the DataService class that provides comprehensive data operations across multiple entities. Explain the primary method deletePurchaseAndTransactions which ensures referential integrity by first deleting associated transactions before removing the parent purchase. Document the loadPurchases, loadCreditCards, and loadPersons methods that retrieve and transform data with expanded relationships for consistent UI consumption. Include the createPurchaseWithTransactions method that orchestrates the creation of a purchase and automatically generates installment transactions based on billing rules. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how date calculations are performed for installment scheduling and how data is transformed with the 'expand' property. Explain the service's role in maintaining data consistency and business rules enforcement. Address common issues such as transaction rollback failures, date calculation edge cases (e.g., month boundaries), and performance implications of batch operations. Include guidance on extending the service to support data export or reporting features.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the PasswordForm component used in the site authentication flow. Explain its implementation for handling password submission, integration with authService for credential verification, and cookie-based authentication state management. Document form structure, error handling for invalid passwords, and loading states during authentication requests. Describe its usage in the /enter-password page and integration with middleware for route protection. Address security considerations such as password input masking, prevention of credential leakage, and protection against brute force attempts. Provide guidance on customizing the authentication flow or extending it with additional security factors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section. Thoroughly explain implementation details of the password-based authentication system, including the invocation relationship between the enter-password page, authService, and site-auth API endpoint. Document the domain model with authentication cookies and environment variables. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing form submission, API request handling, and middleware verification. Explain configuration options like SITE_PASSWORD environment variable and cookie security settings. Address common issues such as authentication failures and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers regarding secure authentication practices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Credit Card Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section. Thoroughly explain implementation details of managing credit cards including principal and supplementary cards, covering the invocation relationship between the credit-cards page, CreditCardForm component, and creditCardService. Document the domain model with CreditCard interface and database schema. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing form validation, service calls, and data display. Explain configuration options and parameters for card creation and editing. Address common issues such as duplicate card entries and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers regarding data relationships and validation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Person Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section. Thoroughly explain implementation details of managing persons who make purchases, covering the invocation relationship between the persons page, PersonForm component, and personService. Document the domain model with Person interface and database schema. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing CRUD operations and data loading. Explain configuration options and parameters for person management. Address common issues such as orphaned records when deleting persons and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers regarding data integrity and service implementation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Purchase Tracking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section. Thoroughly explain implementation details of tracking purchases with installment and BNPL support, covering the invocation relationship between purchase pages, PurchaseForm, PurchaseDetailsCard, and purchaseService. Document the domain model with Purchase interface and database schema. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing purchase creation, details display, and transaction generation. Explain configuration options like installment count and billing dates. Address common issues such as incorrect transaction calculations and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers regarding business logic and data relationships.

wiki_catalogs.name: Transaction Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section. Thoroughly explain implementation details of managing transactions including payment status tracking, covering the invocation relationship between transaction pages, TransactionFilters, dataService, and utility functions. Document the domain model with Transaction interface and database schema. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing transaction filtering, status updates, and data loading. Explain configuration options and parameters for transaction queries. Address common issues such as race conditions during status updates and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers regarding data consistency and UI state management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the application's database schema. Detail entity relationships between Person, CreditCard, Purchase, and Transaction, including field definitions and data types. Document primary/foreign keys, indexes, and constraints such as the relationship between principal and supplementary cards. Explain data validation rules and business rules implemented in Zod schemas. Include database schema diagrams and sample data illustrating typical records. Document data access patterns used in services, caching strategies, and performance considerations for queries. Specify data lifecycle, retention policies, and archival rules. Address data security, privacy requirements, and access control mechanisms.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Endpoints
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the application's public API endpoints. For the /api/site-auth endpoint, document the POST method, request/response schemas, and authentication methods. Include detailed information about request parameters (password), response formats (success/failure), and error handling (400, 401, 500). Document authentication methods using cookie-based tokens and security considerations like HTTP-only cookies. Include protocol-specific examples of API calls from the frontend, error handling strategies, and rate limiting considerations. Address common use cases, client implementation guidelines, and performance optimization tips for API consumption. Provide migration paths if additional endpoints are added in the future.

wiki_catalogs.name: Development Setup Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on setting up the development environment for the credit-card-tracker application. Explain the prerequisites including Node.js, pnpm, and a Supabase account. Document the step-by-step setup process: cloning the repository, installing dependencies with pnpm, configuring environment variables from .env.example, and starting the development server. Include practical examples of common commands like 'pnpm dev' and troubleshooting tips for typical setup issues such as missing dependencies or incorrect environment variables. Provide guidance on connecting to a Supabase instance and seeding the database with sample data. Make the content accessible to beginners while including advanced tips for experienced developers regarding environment configuration and debugging.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Credit Card Tracker

## 1. Project Introduction

The Credit Card Tracker is a web application designed to help users monitor and manage their credit card spending, including installment payments and BNPL (Buy Now, Pay Later) purchases. The application provides a centralized interface for tracking transactions across multiple credit cards and individuals.

**Purpose**: To provide users with visibility into their credit card spending patterns, upcoming payments, and financial obligations through an intuitive interface.

**Core Goals**:
- Track credit card transactions and installment plans
- Manage multiple credit cards and cardholders
- Visualize spending patterns and payment schedules
- Secure access with password-based authentication

**Target Audience**: Individuals who use multiple credit cards or have installment-based purchases and want to maintain better control over their personal finances.

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

The application follows a Next.js App Router architecture with a clear separation of concerns:

- **App Directory**: Contains route handlers and page components
- **Components**: Reusable UI components organized by feature domain
- **Lib**: Business logic, services, constants, and utilities
- **Styles**: Design system and styling configuration

### Design Patterns

The project implements several architectural patterns:

- **Service Pattern**: Data access and business logic are encapsulated in service classes (e.g., `PersonService`, `CreditCardService`)
- **Composition Pattern**: UI components are composed from smaller, reusable base components
- **State Management**: Client-side state is managed through React hooks and server-side data fetching
- **Authentication**: Cookie-based authentication with protected routes

### System Relationships

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client] --> B[Next.js App Router]
    B --> C[Page Components]
    C --> D[UI Components]
    D --> E[Base Components]
    C --> F[Service Layer]
    F --> G[Supabase Client]
    G --> H[(Supabase Database)]
    I[Authentication] --> J[Middleware]
    J --> K[Cookies]
```

### Data Flow

```mermaid
flowchart LR
    A[User Interaction] --> B[UI Component]
    B --> C[Service Call]
    C --> D[Supabase API]
    D --> E[Database]
    E --> F[Data Response]
    F --> G[State Update]
    G --> H[UI Re-render]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `src/app/page.tsx`: Home page with navigation cards and how-it-works section
- `src/app/layout.tsx`: Root layout component
- `src/middleware.ts`: Authentication middleware

### Core Modules
- `src/lib/services/`: Data access services for persons, credit cards, purchases, and transactions
- `src/components/`: UI components organized by feature domain
- `src/lib/supabase.ts`: Supabase client configuration and type definitions

### Configuration Approach
- `next.config.ts`: Next.js configuration
- `package.json`: Project dependencies and scripts
- Environment variables for Supabase configuration

### External Dependencies
- **Supabase**: Backend-as-a-Service for data storage and authentication
- **Next.js**: React framework for server-side rendering and routing
- **Tailwind CSS**: Utility-first CSS framework
- **daisyUI**: Component library built on top of Tailwind CSS
- **Zod**: Schema validation
- **React 19**: UI library

### Integration Points
- Supabase API integration for data persistence
- Cookie-based authentication system
- Environment variable configuration for Supabase connection

### Component Relationship Diagram

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Home Page] --> B[Navigation Cards]
    A --> C[How It Works Section]
    D[Credit Cards Page] --> E[CreditCardForm]
    F[Purchases Page] --> G[PurchaseForm]
    G --> H[Transaction Generation]
    I[Transactions Page] --> J[TransactionFilters]
    K[Persons Page] --> L[PersonForm]
    M[Service Layer] --> N[Supabase Client]
    O[Authentication] --> P[PasswordForm]
    P --> Q[Cookies]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview

The application provides several key features for credit card spending management:

1. **Credit Card Management**: Add, view, and manage credit cards including supplementary cards
2. **Person Management**: Track purchases by different individuals
3. **Purchase Tracking**: Record purchases with installment plans or BNPL arrangements
4. **Transaction Management**: View and update payment status for individual transactions
5. **Authentication**: Password-protected access to financial data

### Implementation Highlights

**Home Page Navigation**: The home page presents a grid of navigation cards that direct users to different sections of the application, providing an intuitive entry point to core functionality.

**Automatic Transaction Generation**: When a purchase with installments is created, the system automatically generates the corresponding transactions with calculated dates and amounts.

**Related Data Loading**: Services fetch data with related entities using Supabase's select syntax with expanded relationships, reducing the need for multiple API calls.

**Authentication Flow**: The application uses middleware to protect routes and a simple cookie-based authentication system.

### Feature Architecture

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Unauthenticated
    Unauthenticated --> EnterPassword: Access Protected Route
    EnterPassword --> Authenticated: Valid Password
    Authenticated --> Home: Dashboard
    Home --> ManageCreditCards: Navigate
    Home --> ManagePurchases: Navigate
    Home --> ViewTransactions: Navigate
    ManagePurchases --> CreatePurchase: Add New
    CreatePurchase --> GenerateTransactions: Installments
    GenerateTransactions --> ViewTransactions: Complete
    Authenticated --> Logout: End Session
    Logout --> Unauthenticated: Clear Cookie
```

### Data Model Relationships

```mermaid
erDiagram
    PERSON ||--o{ PURCHASE : "makes"
    PERSON ||--o{ TRANSACTION : "pays"
    CREDIT_CARD ||--o{ PURCHASE : "used for"
    CREDIT_CARD ||--o{ TRANSACTION : "charged"
    PURCHASE ||--o{ TRANSACTION : "generates"
    CREDIT_CARD ||--o{ CREDIT_CARD : "has supplementary"
```

Sources:
- [package.json](package.json)
- [next.config.ts](next.config.ts)
- [page.tsx](src/app/page.tsx)
- [supabase.ts](src/lib/supabase.ts)
- [dataService.ts](src/lib/services/dataService.ts)
- [personService.ts](src/lib/services/personService.ts)
- [creditCardService.ts](src/lib/services/creditCardService.ts)
- [purchaseService.ts](src/lib/services/purchaseService.ts)
- [auth-constants.ts](src/lib/constants/auth-constants.ts)
</blog>
